title: The most important century in human history

title: When you're an ant but also a fungus tycoon - Charles Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of nutrients for the fungus in a leafcutter ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: The fungus consumes the leaves brought back by the workers.

options.label: B
options.text: The fungus consumes the feces of the ants.

options.label: C
options.text: The fungus consumes the debris and pathogens cleaned off the leaves.

options.label: D
options.text: The fungus consumes the infertile eggs laid by the ants.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the fungus and the leafcutter ants?

options.label: A
options.text: The fungus is a predator that kills the ants.

options.label: B
options.text: The fungus is a parasite that feeds on the ants.

options.label: C
options.text: The fungus is a mutualistic organism that provides essential nutrients to the ants in exchange for care and nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: The fungus is a competitor that competes with the ants for resources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pheromones left on the trails by the foragers?

options.label: A
options.text: To mark the trails as belonging to the colony.

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate the location of food to other ants.

options.label: C
options.text: To recruit other ants to follow the trails.

options.label: D
options.text: To maintain the trails as efficient highways by guiding other ants and preventing trail degradation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the cockroaches in the leafcutter ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: They are predators that feed on the ants.

options.label: B
options.text: They are parasites that feed on the fungus and harm the ants.

options.label: C
options.text: They are mutualistic organisms that help to break down organic matter.

options.label: D
options.text: They are commensal organisms that feed on the fungus without providing any benefit to the ants, while mimicking the ants' scent to avoid detection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the parasitic micro-fungus that threatens the leafcutter ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: Escovopsis.

options.label: B
options.text: Ophiocordyceps.

options.label: C
options.text: Fusarium.

options.label: D
options.text: Aspergillus.

multiple-choice.question: How do the leafcutter ants defend themselves against the parasitic micro-fungus Escovopsis?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce chemical defenses to repel the fungus.

options.label: B
options.text: They use physical barriers to prevent the fungus from infecting the colony.

options.label: C
options.text: They partner with other microorganisms to stunt the growth of the fungus.

options.label: D
options.text: They rigorously weed Escovopsis out of the colony and use a combination of methods to control its growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the leafcutter ants and the fungus they cultivate?

options.label: A
options.text: The ants are predators that feed on the fungus.

options.label: B
options.text: The ants are parasites that feed on the fungus.

options.label: C
options.text: The ants are mutualistic organisms that provide nutrients to the fungus in exchange for essential nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: The ants are competitors that compete with the fungus for resources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the leafcutter ants' "gardening" behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a physical barrier to protect the colony from predators.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a chemical signal to recruit other ants to the colony.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a fungal garden that provides essential nutrients to the ants.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a physical structure to store food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which the leafcutter ants domesticated the fungus they cultivate?

options.label: A
options.text: Co-evolution through a process of natural selection.

options.label: B
options.text: Mutualism.

options.label: C
options.text: Symbiosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Domestication through a process of artificial selection.

multiple-choice.question: How long can a leafcutter ant queen live?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 1 year.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 5 years.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 10 years or more.

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 20 years.

title: The man who lost his sense of touch - Antonio Cataldo

multiple-choice.question: What rare neurological condition was Ian Waterman diagnosed with, which interrupted certain signals from his nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: Deafferentation

options.label: B
options.text: Peripheral neuropathy

options.label: C
options.text: Somatosensory disorder

options.label: D
options.text: Multiple sclerosis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the somatosensory system in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature and heart rate

options.label: B
options.text: To process visual and auditory information

options.label: C
options.text: To oversee all sensations arising from the surface and interior of the body

options.label: D
options.text: To control muscle movement and reflexes

multiple-choice.question: Which type of receptor cells are responsible for sensing mechanical deformation of the skin, such as vibrations, stretch, or pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Thermoreceptors

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanoreceptors

options.label: C
options.text: Nociceptors

options.label: D
options.text: Proprioceptors

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of rubbing an injury on pain relief, and why does it occur?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the pain due to increased inflammation

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on pain relief

options.label: C
options.text: It temporarily relieves the pain due to thicker fibers carrying tactile information overriding pain signals

options.label: D
options.text: It causes permanent damage to nerve endings

multiple-choice.question: What can be the result of damage to the somatosensory system, depending on the location and extent of the damage?

options.label: A
options.text: The loss of certain sensations in particular locations

options.label: B
options.text: The complete loss of all sensations

options.label: C
options.text: The gain of new sensations and reflexes

options.label: D
options.text: No effect on bodily functions

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the condition characterized by anxiety, depression, high blood pressure, and a weakened immune system due to deprivation of social touch?

options.label: A
options.text: Touch starvation

options.label: B
options.text: Somatosensory disorder

options.label: C
options.text: Deafferentation

options.label: D
options.text: Tactile hypersensitivity

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain in processing sensory information from the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out unnecessary sensory information

options.label: B
options.text: To combine sensory data to move through space without needing to see limbs

options.label: C
options.text: To prioritize visual information over other senses

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore sensory information from the skin and muscles

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of mechanoreceptors in the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To sense temperature changes and pain

options.label: B
options.text: To sense the position of the body in space

options.label: C
options.text: To sense mechanical deformation of the skin

options.label: D
options.text: To sense changes in blood pressure

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of an autoimmune reaction attacking a large swath of Ian Waterman's nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: Deafferentation, resulting in no tactile or proprioceptive sensations from the neck down

options.label: B
options.text: Somatosensory disorder, resulting in loss of certain sensations

options.label: C
options.text: Peripheral neuropathy, resulting in muscle weakness

options.label: D
options.text: Complete loss of all sensations and reflexes

multiple-choice.question: What is an important role of touch in movement, as demonstrated by Ian Waterman's case?

options.label: A
options.text: To gauge strength in a situation and react to pain

options.label: B
options.text: To navigate through space using visual information only

options.label: C
options.text: To move without seeing limbs by using proprioception

options.label: D
options.text: To provide feedback on body position and movement

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon does the speaker describe as the tendency to imagine that we will remain the same in the future, despite changes in our perspectives and preferences?

options.label: A
options.text: The ship of Theseus paradox

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of psychological plasticity

options.label: C
options.text: The problem of personal growth

options.label: D
options.text: The illusion of continuity

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do we tend to imagine that we will remain the same in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we lack self-awareness

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are too focused on the present moment

options.label: C
options.text: Because we can see the contrast between our past and present selves, but not our future selves

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are unaware of the changes that will occur in our lives

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of John and Stephanie Rinka used to illustrate in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of advance directives in medical decision-making

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of the ship of Theseus

options.label: C
options.text: The challenges of making promises to future selves

options.label: D
options.text: How people's views on life and death can change over time

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main problem with making promises to future selves?

options.label: A
options.text: That we may not have the capacity to keep them

options.label: B
options.text: That our future selves may not share our current views and perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: That we may not be able to fulfill our promises due to external circumstances

options.label: D
options.text: That our future selves may not be interested in keeping promises

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for dealing with the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the present moment and not worry about the future

options.label: B
options.text: To ignore the changes that will occur in our lives

options.label: C
options.text: To stay curious, expand our horizons, and take an active role in crafting our future selves

options.label: D
options.text: To be more confident in our views and opinions

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why is humility important in dealing with the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to be more confident in our views and opinions

options.label: B
options.text: It enables us to make promises to future selves with confidence

options.label: C
options.text: It helps us to recognize the limitations of our knowledge and understanding

options.label: D
options.text: It helps us to ignore the changes that will occur in our lives

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's third piece of advice for dealing with the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the present moment and not worry about the future

options.label: B
options.text: To be more confident in our views and opinions

options.label: C
options.text: To be brave and take risks, recognizing that our future selves may have capacities and strengths we don't possess today

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the changes that will occur in our lives

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between our past and future selves?

options.label: A
options.text: Our past selves are identical to our future selves

options.label: B
options.text: Our past selves are completely different from our future selves

options.label: C
options.text: Our past selves are similar to our future selves, but with some differences

options.label: D
options.text: Our past selves may be a stranger to our future selves, with different perspectives and preferences

multiple-choice.question: What concept is the ship of Theseus used to illustrate in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our bodies are made up of different cells over time

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of psychological plasticity and how our brains change over time

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that our past and future selves are identical

options.label: D
options.text: The concept that our bodies and selves are made up of different parts over time, but are still the same entity

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main challenge of dealing with the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more confident in our views and opinions

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on the present moment and not worry about the future

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the changes that will occur in our lives

options.label: D
options.text: To accept and adapt to the idea that we will be different people in the future

title: How did they build the Great Pyramid of Giza? - Soraya Field Fiorio

multiple-choice.question: When did Pharaoh Khufu ascend the throne and begin work on his eternal resting place?

options.label: A
options.text: 2500 BCE

title: Is it possible to lose weight fast? - Hei Man Chan

multiple-choice.question: In Victorian England's wealthiest circles, what unusual and unhealthy method did some people use to manage their weight?

options.label: A
options.text: The Starvation Diet

options.label: B
options.text: The Detoxification Diet

options.label: C
options.text: The Low-Calorie Diet

options.label: D
options.text: The Tapeworm Diet

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of Sam's diet plan, and how does it differ from Felix's approach?

options.label: A
options.text: To rapidly lose weight through extreme calorie reduction

options.label: B
options.text: To maintain his current weight through a balanced diet

options.label: C
options.text: To drastically reduce his calorie intake for rapid weight loss

options.label: D
options.text: To gradually decrease his calorie intake and increase his regular exercise

multiple-choice.question: What happens to Felix's body after 18 hours of drastically reducing his calorie intake?

options.label: A
options.text: It starts breaking down his fat cells as a major energy source

options.label: B
options.text: It starts breaking down his muscles for energy

options.label: C
options.text: It replenishes his glycogen store

options.label: D
options.text: It breaks down his entire store of emergency glucose

multiple-choice.question: How does Felix's low-calorie diet affect his muscle mass compared to Sam's approach?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases his muscle mass through intense exercise

options.label: B
options.text: It maintains his muscle mass through regular exercise

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on his muscle mass

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases his muscle mass due to inadequate nutrition

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between Sam's diet plan and Felix's diet plan?

options.label: A
options.text: Sam's plan focuses on rapid weight loss, while Felix's plan focuses on gradual weight loss

options.label: B
options.text: Sam's plan emphasizes exercise, while Felix's plan emphasizes diet

options.label: C
options.text: Sam's plan is tailored to his nutritional needs, while Felix's plan is not

options.label: D
options.text: Sam's plan involves gradual calorie reduction and regular exercise, while Felix's plan involves drastic calorie reduction

multiple-choice.question: How does Felix's diet affect his body's basic functions in terms of energy expenditure?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases his energy levels through intense exercise

options.label: B
options.text: It maintains his energy levels through a balanced diet

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on his energy levels

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases his energy levels, causing him to burn fewer calories

multiple-choice.question: What is a key benefit of Sam's diet plan in terms of its impact on his body?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows him to lose weight rapidly through extreme calorie reduction

options.label: B
options.text: It allows him to maintain his muscle mass through regular exercise

options.label: C
options.text: It replenishes his glycogen store in a healthy manner

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a sustainable energy deficit in his body through a balanced diet and exercise

multiple-choice.question: What is a significant drawback of Felix's diet plan in terms of its impact on his body?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows him to lose weight rapidly and maintain muscle mass

options.label: B
options.text: It allows him to maintain his muscle mass through intense exercise

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on his weight or muscle mass

options.label: D
options.text: It causes him to lose muscle mass and burn fewer calories

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential risk of a prolonged juice diet in terms of its impact on the immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases immune function through high levels of essential nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: It maintains immune function through a balanced mix of nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on immune function

options.label: D
options.text: It compromises immune function due to a lack of essential fats and proteins

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary recommendation of the text for achieving healthy weight loss?

options.label: A
options.text: To try to lose weight rapidly through extreme calorie reduction

options.label: B
options.text: To cut out certain food groups for rapid weight loss

options.label: C
options.text: To follow a juice diet for detoxification

options.label: D
options.text: To adopt a sustainable dietary lifestyle that accounts for genetic and medical differences

title: The myth of Zeus' test - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What did the two mysterious figures ask for when they knocked on every door in the hillside village?

options.label: A
options.text: Directions to the nearest town

options.label: B
options.text: Shelter from an impending storm

options.label: C
options.text: Food and shelter

options.label: D
options.text: Help with their journey

multiple-choice.question: What was distinctive about Baucis and Philemon's nature?

options.label: A
options.text: They prioritized their own needs above all else

options.label: B
options.text: They showed kindness only to their friends and family

options.label: C
options.text: They were kind and caring, especially to those in need

options.label: D
options.text: They were indifferent to the needs of others

multiple-choice.question: What did Philemon add to the stew to honor their guests, despite it being a rare luxury for the couple?

options.label: A
options.text: Freshly harvested vegetables from their garden

options.label: B
options.text: Freshly baked bread from their oven

options.label: C
options.text: Strips of meat from an aging shank

options.label: D
options.text: Exotic spices from a distant land

multiple-choice.question: What did Baucis use to balance the wobbly table's legs and make it stable?

options.label: A
options.text: A piece of wood from the nearby forest

options.label: B
options.text: A metal rod from their toolkit

options.label: C
options.text: A chip of broken glass

options.label: D
options.text: A chip of broken clay

multiple-choice.question: What miraculous event occurred with the clay vessel as the night wore on and the guests drank wine?

options.label: A
options.text: It was broken and spilled wine everywhere

options.label: B
options.text: It was replaced with a new, fuller vessel

options.label: C
options.text: It ran out of wine, causing concern for the couple

options.label: D
options.text: It never ran dry, despite the guests' hearty consumption

multiple-choice.question: Who were the two gods in disguise that Baucis and Philemon's guests ultimately revealed themselves to be?

options.label: A
options.text: Poseidon and Hades, rulers of the sea and underworld

options.label: B
options.text: Athena and Artemis, goddesses of wisdom and the hunt

options.label: C
options.text: Apollo and Ares, gods of the sun and war

options.label: D
options.text: Zeus and Hermes, the king of the gods and the messenger

multiple-choice.question: What punishment did Zeus and Hermes inflict upon the townspeople for refusing to shelter them?

options.label: A
options.text: They were turned into animals as punishment for their cruelty

options.label: B
options.text: They were turned into statues as a warning to others

options.label: C
options.text: They were cast underwater, leaving their village a murky swamp

options.label: D
options.text: They were forced to leave their homes and wander the earth

multiple-choice.question: What requests did Baucis and Philemon make when given the opportunity to ask for anything from the gods?

options.label: A
options.text: They asked to be taken to the underworld to serve the gods

options.label: B
options.text: They asked to be given wealth and power to live a life of luxury

options.label: C
options.text: They asked to be allowed to care for the new temple and to die together

options.label: D
options.text: They asked to be given immortality to live forever on earth

multiple-choice.question: What transformation occurred to Baucis and Philemon when they eventually passed away?

options.label: A
options.text: They were taken to the underworld to serve the gods

options.label: B
options.text: They were turned into animals to roam the earth in a new form

options.label: C
options.text: They were turned into statues to stand guard over the temple

options.label: D
options.text: They were transformed into intertwined trees, their love enduring

multiple-choice.question: What specific types of trees did Baucis and Philemon's bodies transform into when they died, symbolizing their eternal love?

options.label: A
options.text: A single tree with two trunks, symbolizing unity

options.label: B
options.text: Two separate trees standing apart, representing individuality

options.label: C
options.text: A linden and an oak tree with intertwined branches

options.label: D
options.text: A pair of stones marking their graves, a testament to their love

title: The original ring of power - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: According to the legend of the Ring of Gyges, who was the original owner of the ring?

options.label: A
options.text: The king of Lydia

options.label: B
options.text: A shepherd named Gyges

options.label: C
options.text: A giant

options.label: D
options.text: Socrates

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument presented by Glaucon in the story of the Ring of Gyges?

options.label: A
options.text: That people act justly because it is inherently right and beneficial

options.label: B
options.text: That people act justly due to external influences and the consequences of their actions

options.label: C
options.text: That justice has no benefits or drawbacks

options.label: D
options.text: That people are naturally virtuous without external influences

multiple-choice.question: According to Glaucon, what class of good does justice belong to?

options.label: A
options.text: The first class, desired for its own sake

options.label: B
options.text: The second class, desired for the value it brings despite being a burden

options.label: C
options.text: The third class, desired for its own sake and the value it offers

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the main disagreement between Socrates and Glaucon in the story of the Ring of Gyges?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether people act justly due to external influences or for their own sake

options.label: B
options.text: Whether justice belongs to the second or third class of good

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the Ring of Gyges has supernatural powers that are morally justifiable

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the king of Lydia was a just ruler

multiple-choice.question: According to Socrates, what are the three parts of the human soul?

options.label: A
options.text: Reason, spirit, and appetite

options.label: B
options.text: Reason, courage, and wisdom

options.label: C
options.text: Reason, spirit, and knowledge

options.label: D
options.text: Reason, appetite, and ignorance

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between reason and appetite in the human soul, according to Socrates?

options.label: A
options.text: Reason directly influences appetite without any intermediaries

options.label: B
options.text: Appetite directly influences reason without any control

options.label: C
options.text: Reason and appetite are equal and independent

options.label: D
options.text: Reason guides an individual and keeps appetite in check through the spirit

multiple-choice.question: Which Chinese philosopher similarly reasoned that by simply acting justly, one also benefits oneself?

options.label: A
options.text: Confucius

options.label: B
options.text: Lao Tzu

options.label: C
options.text: Mencius

options.label: D
options.text: Zhuangzi

multiple-choice.question: What is Thomas Hobbes' main argument regarding human nature and justice?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are naturally obligated to act justly due to their inherent goodness

options.label: B
options.text: That people agree to participate in civil society to secure their natural rights

options.label: C
options.text: That the state of nature is inherently violent and selfish, and justice is imposed by authority

options.label: D
options.text: That justice is unnecessary in a civil society

multiple-choice.question: What is John Locke's main argument regarding human nature and justice?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are naturally violent and selfish without any regard for justice

options.label: B
options.text: That justice is imposed by authority without any natural obligations

options.label: C
options.text: That people agree to participate in civil society to secure their natural rights

options.label: D
options.text: That the state of nature is inherently just without any need for civil society

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the term "Free Lances" in the context of employment, as described in Sir Walter Scott's novel "Ivanhoe"?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of employment contract in the Middle Ages

options.label: B
options.text: Mercenary soldiers who were free to use their lances in service of whoever paid the most

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who work together in a traditional job

options.label: D
options.text: A form of business partnership in the 19th century

What benefits may freelancers not automatically receive, unlike those in traditional employment?

options.label: A
options.text: Health insurance and paid vacation

options.label: B
options.text: Life insurance and retirement plans

options.label: C
options.text: Paid vacation, life insurance, and sick leave

options.label: D
options.text: Health insurance, paid vacation, life insurance, college tuition, retirement plans, and sick leave

options.label: A
options.text: They provide too many benefits to their users

options.label: B
options.text: They offer too much flexibility in work schedules

options.label: C
options.text: They can be inflexible and may not allow users to choose their own routes or rates

options.label: D
options.text: They guarantee a reliable living wage

options.label: B
options.text: $18 an hour

options.label: C
options.text: $12 an hour

options.label: D
options.text: $20 an hour

options.label: A
options.text: A network of researchers

options.label: B
options.text: The Fair Labor Association

options.label: C
options.text: The Digital Gig Platform Ratings Network

options.label: D
options.text: The Employment Standards Research Network

multiple-choice.question: Why is the gig economy sometimes referred to as an "alternative safety net"?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a reliable living wage

options.label: B
options.text: It is the easiest and fastest place to get hired for those who need to make money quickly

options.label: C
options.text: It provides more benefits than traditional employment

options.label: D
options.text: It is a better option for freelancers

multiple-choice.question: What factors should you consider when deciding whether to join the gig economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Flexibility, autonomy, networking, self-directedness, and the value of knowing exactly what you'll earn from week to week

options.label: B
options.text: Only flexibility and autonomy

options.label: C
options.text: Only the value of knowing exactly what you'll earn from week to week

options.label: D
options.text: Job security and benefits

multiple-choice.question: What type of work arrangement is typically involved in the gig economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Traditional employment

options.label: B
options.text: Freelancing or independent contracting

options.label: C
options.text: Part-time or full-time employment

options.label: D
options.text: Business partnership

multiple-choice.question: What characteristics of the gig economy set it apart from traditional employment?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to work remotely

options.label: B
options.text: The flexibility to choose one's own hours and work schedule

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for variable pay and benefits

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above, including independence and flexibility
